history.subject: One js file for multiple webpages or one js file for each webpage?
history.content: Hi my team decided to create a website that contains several pages, the layout would be relatively simple and so does the functions of each page. I used to put all the styling in the same CSS file, but I'm not sure if I use one js file to handle  the interaction from different pages, or should I create separate js file for the different webpages?

It would probably be a good idea to separate the JS files for the different webpage, especially if that JS code is only used on one of the many pages. This is good not only for modularity but also if there's a logical error you don't have to go through like 1000 lines of code, just the lines of code that that specific page uses.

I found this post, seems useful: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4634644/how-to-include-js-file-in-another-js-file

And, you should split up your css files for readability and maintainability.\xa0

For example, you have style.css as the main css file, then page1.css, page2.css and page3.css

In your style.css, you can set global properties that will apply to all css files, like font-family, font color, a tag properties, a:hover, nav bar, etc.

In pageX.css, you set some specific properties that will apply to only that page.

Then you can include them in style.css like this:

@import 'page1.css'
@import 'page2.css'
@import 'page3.css'

That way, in your index.html, you only need to include style.css in the head section

I found this post, seem useful: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4634644/how-to-include-js-file-in-another-js-file

And, you should split up your css files for readability and maintainability.\xa0

For example, you have style.css as the main css file, then page1.css, page2.css and page3.css

In your style.css, you can set global properties that will apply to all css files, like font-family, font color, a tag properties, a:hover, nav bar, etc.

In pageX.css, you set some specific properties that will apply to only that page.

Then you can include them in style.css like this:

@import 'page1.css'
@import 'page2.css'
@import 'page3.css'

That way, in your index.html, you only need to include style.css in the head section
